But though she’s a factory lass
 And wears no fancy clothes.
 Baraabum.
 Yet I’ve a sort of a
 Yorkshire relish for
 My little Yorkshire rose.
 Baraabum.

Lyrics from My Girl’s a Yorkshire Girl (Murphy and Lipton

http://www.james-joyce-music.com/song10_lyrics.html
Eternal punishment
Haines concludes his speculation about Stephen’s idee fixe. He thinks Stephen is obsessed with damnation.
He is going to write something in ten years
Ulysses is set in 1904, and Joyce began writing the novel in 1914.
A Stuart face of nonesuch Charles, lank locks falling at its sides

Stephen compares his sister Dilly’s face to that of Charles Stuart. Charles I, Charles II, and Bonny Prince Charlie were all named Charles Stuart. There were many other Charles Stuarts in the peerage.

Charles I was executed and had “lank locks” so perhaps he is the nonesuch Charles Stuart which Stephen evokes.
At the siege of Ross did my father fall

A line from The Croppy Boy:

At the siege of Ross did my father fall,
And at Gorey my loving brothers all.
I alone am left of my name and race;
I will go to Wexford and take their place.

http://www.james-joyce-music.com/song16_lyrics.html
The Featherbed Mountain

The Wicklow Mountains, which are south of Dublin.

http://www.joyceproject.com/notes/010010mountains.htm
Ma, sul serio, eh
Italian: “But, seriously, eh?”
Ci rifletterò
Italian: “I will think about it.”
Di che? Almidano Artifoni said. Scusi, eh? Tante belle cose!
Italian: “For what? Excuse me, alright? All the best!”
Arrivederla, maestro, Stephen said, raising his hat when his hand was freed. E grazie
Italian: “Goodbye maestro. And thanks.”
